title: How the Federal Reserve Could Inflate or Pop an AI Bubble
description: Despite mounting evidence that artificial intelligence stocks are increasingly frothy, some analysts believe valuations and prices could go even higher if the Federal Reserve continues cutting interest rates to stimulate a weakening economy.
content: Concerns about an AI bubble have some on Wall Street warily eyeing Silicon Valley, but others say they're looking in the wrong direction. Washington, D.C.—specifically the Eccles Building, where the Federal Open Market Committee sets monetary policy—... [3873 chars]

title: Artificial Intelligence Was Built to Help Humanity, And Not Do This
description: AI has become so common that it now finds its way into almost every sphere of life. From politics to religion, from art to situationships, there is always someone trying to make AI do something it was never meant to do.
content: Artificial Intelligence was built to make our lives easier. It was meant to predict ailments, guide spacecraft, and help mankind with the complex challenges life throws at them. But somewhere along the way, humans decided it should do more and do thi... [3594 chars]

title: YouTube will use AI to enhance the resolution of your videos
description: YouTube said that it would use artificial intelligence (AI) in order to enhance the resolution of creators’ videos.
content:
YouTube on Wednesday (October 29, 2025) introduced a new AI-powered feature to automatically generate higher resolutions for videos.

title: YouTube CEO Neal Mohan announces 'voluntary exit program' for human staff to match its growing focus on AI
description: YouTube is carrying out a major internal reorganization to strengthen its focus on artificial intelligence, CEO Neal Mohan announced.

title: AI use in Georgia courts brings harsh consequences
description: Georgia lawyers and self-represented litigants have run into trouble with judges after using artificial intelligence to create legal arguments.
content:
Legal filings riddled with fake, irrelevant and misconstrued case citations are increasingly appearing in front of Georgia judges as the use of artificial intelligence to craft arguments becomes more common.
